caption_original: Canadian Coast Guard Atlantic HQ recently met with partners from National Defence aboard the CCGS Ann Harvey in refit, in St. John’s, Newfoundland & Labrador. Rear-Admiral John Newton, Commander Maritime Forces Atlantic and Joint Task Force Atlantic, and his colleagues Major Mark Norris, Officer in Charge of the Joint Rescue Coordination Centre (Halifax), Lieutenant Commander Jordan Holder and Lieutenant (Navy) Stephen Lamarche were joined by Assistant Commissioner CCG Atlantic Wade Spurrell, and given a tour of CCGS Ann Harvey by Jeff Seitz, Superintendent Marine Engineering.
caption_cleaned: Canadian Coast Guard Atlantic HQ recently met with partners from National Defence aboard the CCGS Ann Harvey in refit, in St. John’s, Newfoundland & Labrador. Rear-Admiral John Newton, Commander Maritime Forces Atlantic and Joint Task Force Atlantic, and his colleagues Major Mark Norris, Officer in Charge of the Joint Rescue Coordination Centre (Halifa, Lieutenant Commander Jordan Holder and Lieutenant (Navy) Stephen Lamarche were joined by Assistant Commissioner CCG Atlantic Wade Spurrell, and given a tour of CCGS Ann Harvey by Jeff Seitz, Superintendent Marine Engineering.

caption_original: The Canadian Coast Guard College marine engineering simulator replicates a typical engine room and control room that would be found on board any Canadian Coast Guard vessel. Officer Cadets experience watchkeeping routines and must monitor the performance of various pumps, engines, and other systems on board ship. http://ow.ly/F32b30dJvpt

caption_original: The weather was just perfect for yesterday’s Pride Parade in St. John’s, Newfoundland and Labrador! CCG Atlantic Assistant Commissioner Wade Spurrell and our colleagues are proud to celebrate the occasion, and the diversity of our Canadian Coast Guard team.

caption_original: History Week 2017 - our members are an important part of our history! Miles Taylor has been with the Canadian Coast Guard for over 49 years. As a logistics officer his job is to make sure this ship, the CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier, has everything it needs on board to operate for four months in the Arctic. Miles has been to the Arctic every year but one since 1980.

Miles has been to the Arctic every year but one since .

caption_original: Joanne Murphy of DFO NL’s Regional Property, Safety and Security group recently took these pictures of the Canadian Coast Guard Ship Vladykov off the coast of Bonavista Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador from a CCG helicopter while enroute to Puffin Island in Bonavista Bay for routine light station maintenance.

caption_original:
Our Marine Communications and Traffic  Services Officers work hard to keep our waters safe throughout the country 24/7/365. Managing marine traffic means keeping a keen eye on the radars, much like providing “air traffic control for the water”. With the arrival of the Tall Ships in Halifax Harbour this week, both MCTS Officers and mariners can expect an increase on-water traffic. 
https://www.thecoast.ca/halifax/air-traffic-control-for-the-water/Content?oid=8605906

With the arrival of the Tall Ships in Halifax Harbour this week, both MCTS Officers and mariners can eect an increase on-water traffic.

caption_original: Have the Tall Ships at the Port of Québec sparked your interest in the sea and inspired you to learn about the maritime sector and the life of seafaring personnel? caption_original: Thank you to our dedicated search and rescue personnel and our partners for their hard work together in their recent mission on Lake Erie, Ontario. We’re so glad everyone made it home safe, and we’re proud to be of service. Jana Lorbetski, a Canadian Coast Guard rescue specialist, said that bringing the individuals to safety “felt like winning the jackpot.”
caption_cleaned: Thank you to our dedicated search and rescue personnel and our partners for their hard work together in their recent mission on Lake Erie, Ontario. We’re so glad everyone made it home safe, and we’re proud to be of service. Jana Lorbetski, a Canadian Coast Guard rescue specialist, said that bringing the individuals to safety “felt like winning the jackpot.”

caption_original: History Week 2017 - The origins of a Canadian Coast Guard can be traced to as far back as the 1700s when the first lifeboats and lighthouses were established in Eastern Canada. caption_original: Our Maritime and Civil Infrastructure team travelled to Scaterie Island off Cape Breton, Nova Scotia last month. The three-day project included slinging, removal, and installation of numerous solar panels for the aid to navigation.

caption_original: The St. Lawrence River is full of boats on the water participating in and observing the Tall Ships Regatta in Quebec City. Please be vigilant when you’re navigating these waters. Marine traffic will be particularly heavy until July 23rd. Familiarize yourself with the Canadian Coast Guard’s Aids to Navigation before boarding: http://www.ccg-gcc.gc.ca/aids/home

caption_original: Public reminder: the Battery Point Breakwater fog horn in Nova Scotia is an aid to navigation designed to help keep mariners safe. Unnecessary activation of of the fog horn disturbs those in the area & can affect the safety of those on the water.
caption_cleaned: Public reminder: the Battery Point Breakwater fog horn in Nova Scotia is an aid to navigation designed to help keep mariners safe. Unnecessary activation of of the fog horn disturbs those in the area & can affect the safety of those on the water.

caption_original: Our Inshore Rescue Boat summer student program is a great summer job! Students are trained in on-water Search & Rescue operations, and spend the summer making a difference in communities across Canada. Since 2013, the Coast Guard has partnered with the Royal Canadian Navy so naval reserve-force students like Daven, pictured here at our Bamfield Station in British Columbia, can work alongside Coast Guard personnel. Learn more here: http://www.ccg-gcc.gc.ca/sar/irb-background
